review.title: Gender Inference using Statistical Name Characteristics in Twitter
review.abstract: Much attention has been given to the task of gender inference of Twitter users. Although names are strong gender indicators, the names of Twitter users are rarely used as a feature; probably due to the high number of ill-formed names, which cannot be found in any name dictionary. Instead of relying solely on a name database, we propose a novel name classifier. Our approach extracts characteristics from the user names and uses those in order to assign the names to a gender. This enables us to classify international first names as well as ill-formed names.

sections.heading: 3. DATASETS
sections.text: This section describes the data used in this post. First, we present the gender-specific name data that can be used to determine the true gender from a given name. Second, we describe the data used in our Twitter experiments. Note that we considered only "male" and "female" as potential genders of people and ignored sexual identities such as "cisgender" or "transgender" because there is no basic truth available for this.

sections.heading: 3.1 Gender-labeled Name Data
sections.text: A reliable gender-specific dataset dataset is required to make assumptions about the performance of a name-specific gender-dataset classifier. We have decided to use the Census3 and nam dict dataset during our experiments for the following reasons: First, the Census data was used by Liu and Ruths [14], and we will base their results on Section 5. Second, the nam dict dataset is the largest dataset we know that includes non-American names. Following is a brief description of both datasets: Census: The Census dataset was created in 1990 by the US Census Bureau and consists of three files, one for female first names, one for male first names, and one for all surnames. Each file contains for these top dataset datasthe frequency of their use in percent, the cumulative frequency of their use in percent, the frequency of their use in percent, and the frequency of their usage.

sections.heading: 3.2 Twitter Data
sections.text: Here is a brief description of both sets of data: Ground truth: Reliable information about the actual gender of Twitter users is essential for conducting gender-specific experiments; such data is difficult to find and is rarely shared. Liu and Ruth [14] faced the same problem and therefore created their own data set and Twitter sampling: We collected all messages and relevant profile information from Twitter users contained in the Ground Truth data created by Liu and Ruth. Only 9,060 of the 12,681 users could be reached through the Twitter API to date. This breakdown is broken down into 3,471 male and 5,589 female users (according to AMT employees). Reasons for the reduced number of accessible users may be that the data set was collected by male users before their private lives were large, or that both were large before their private lives were deactivated in 2013.

At the end of this section, we present our novel name classifier NamChar and its configuration.

sections.heading: 4.4 Classification Model
sections.text: Inspired by Liu and Ruth, we used an SVM (i.e. LIBSVM [5]) with the basic radial function as the kernel in our SVM model. Following the logistical regression results in Table 4, we included all variables except for the brightness of the vowel and the number of consonants and syllables in our SVM model. We used a grid search technique with a 10-fold cross-validation with three repetitions to find the best parameter, which is γ = 0.1745521 and cost = 1 with an accuracy of 70.9% and a kappa value of 0.419. The standard method for assigning genders to names without classification would be by random guess. On the other hand, our NamChar is able to correctly classify a name in 70.9% cases as mentioned in the previous paragraph. This is a considerable improvement compared to random guesses. We expect the model to work even with unknown names.

sections.heading: 5. TWITTER GENDER INFERENCE
sections.text: We will recall the gender score of Liu and Ruth [14] and introduce our refinement, the NamChar Score. Then we will show how to improve the gender classification of Twitter users by extending the NamChar Threshold Classifier. The basic idea of both approaches is to look up the name in a database, and the stored score is used when the database contains the name. If not, Liu and Ruth [14] use a score of 0.0, while our approach is NamChar.It is important to note that the Nam Score data is used here as input data and not as a basic truth as in Section 4.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: Our first contribution was the suggestion of a novel name classifier - NamChar - that is able to identify a first name as one of the two genders by using only a small set of characteristics extracted from the written first name. We evaluated the performance of all possible name characteristics and selected the statistically significant characteristics. Our second contribution was the introduction of an improved Gender Consequence Classifier for Twitter users. We observed that only using a larger name database will not improve the performance of the Threshold Classifier. The best results were obtained from our NamChar Threshold Classifier. There are some topics that might be interesting for further investigation. It is surprising, for example, that users only used the Lovins text to calculate k-top stems and co-stems during feature calculation. The Porter stemmer [22] has since become a de facto standard and has largely replaced the Lovins.
